intro: Rorippa bonariensis, commonly known as the Argentine watercress, is a flowering plant native to South America. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes other mustard family plants. The plant typically grows in wet environments such as marshes and stream banks, where it thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and often submerged or floating, while its small white or yellow flowers are arranged in racemes. The plant is known for its peppery flavor and has been used in traditional medicine and as a culinary herb.
